docs.snippet: Both Snapchat Stories and the newer Instagram Stories let users experience their friends’ most intimate and endearing moments in a news-free zone.

headline.print_headline: Finally,  a Feed  Without  the News
headline.main: A Charming Alternative Universe of You, Your Friends and No News

docs.snippet: Ireland’s leap year tradition has women asking, “Will you marry me?” But in general, men still propose.

headline.print_headline: Maids All A-Leaping With Marriage Proposals
headline.main: Why Women Proposing Is Still Rare

docs.snippet: The executives meeting with Mr. Trump in Manhattan on Wednesday include Elon Musk of Tesla, Timothy D. Cook of Apple and Jeff Bezos of Amazon.

headline.main: When Trump Meets Tech Leaders, Jobs Will Be on the Agenda

docs.snippet: Also, competitive tipping, roommate troubles and houseguest etiquette on vacation.

headline.main: My Stepmother Calls Herself Mom but Doesn’t Act Like One. What to Do?

docs.abstract: Philip Galanes Social Q's on stepmoms, haircuts, roommates and vacation house-guests.

docs.snippet: Antonio Perkins was streaming video of himself on Facebook Live on Wednesday when he was shot and killed in Chicago.

headline.main: Chicago Man Records Own Fatal Shooting

docs.snippet: In addition to its chat powers, Facebook Messenger can send payments to friends once everyone’s debit cards are linked to the service.
docs.abstract: Tech Tip Q&A; advice given on making payments with Facebook messenger.

docs.snippet: Companies like Amazon and Microsoft are building data centers across the Continent in response to Europeans’ desires to keep their information close to home.

headline.print_headline: U.S. Tech Giants Investing to Keep Data in Europe
headline.main: U.S. Tech Giants Are Investing Billions to Keep Data in Europe

docs.abstract: Amazon, Google and Microsoft are expanding number of data centers in Europe to satisfy European Union privacy laws and protect information stored on servers there from requests by foreign governments; companies are also motivated by profit due to growing demand for cloud computing services in Europe, expected to reach $16.1 billion by end of decade.

docs.snippet: The social network requires a level of trust from its users as it seeks to “make the world more open and connected.” But how open is it willing to be?
docs.abstract: Jim Rutenberg Mediator column raises concerns about way Facebook responded to accusations of political bias in its Trending Topics feed; notes that even as company requires its users to waive much of their privacy, it has operated in way that contradicts its stated commitment to openness, which is particularly troubling given its influence on news media.

docs.snippet: The fiery blast also destroyed a satellite that Facebook had planned to use to expand internet services in Africa.

headline.print_headline: SpaceX Blast Puts Big Goals Into Question
headline.main: SpaceX Rocket Explodes at Launchpad in Cape Canaveral

docs.abstract: SpaceX rocket explodes on its launch platform at Cape Canaveral, Fla, destroying $200 million communications satellite meant to extend Facebook's reach across African continent; blast is setback for company and underscores dangers of NASA's increasing reliance on private space travel companies, as it will also delay cargo deliveries to International Space Station.

docs.snippet: Snooping on you to sell you stuff is so 2015. Now we willingly turn ourselves into advertisements.

headline.main: Daily Report: The Message From Snapchat
